hello I would like to start my talk with

is really strange because on a

12 million pigs and um well of course
the Dutch can't eat all these pigs they
eat about oneir and the rest is exported
to all kinds of countries in Europe and
the rest of the world a lot go to the UK
Germany and what I was curious about
because historically the whole pig would

find out if this was actually still the

Pig with number 050 049 all the way up
until the end uh until what products
it's made of and uh in these years I met
all kinds of people like for instance
farmers and butchers which seems logical
but I also met aluminium mold makers and
ammunition producers and um well all
kinds of people and what was striking to
me is that the far Farmers actually had
no clue of what was made of their pigs
but um the consumers as in us had also
no idea of the pigs being in all these

book you probably start the day with a

but also

used as an improver of

course in lowfat butter or actually in

they put gelatine back in in order to
retain the
texture well when you're off to work
under the road or under the buildings
that you see there might very well be
Cellular Concrete which is a very light

fully reusable in the train brakes at

bone
as and in cheesecake and all kinds of

this is a real classic course the bone
in fine bone china gives it its

deer in interior decorating the pig is

paper and then in paintbrushes hairs are

well it's called portion controlled meat
cut and uh this is actually sold in the

it is it's it's actually steak so this
is sold as cow but what happens when you
slaughter a cow at least in the
industrial well factory farming they
they have all these little bits of steak
left that they can't actually sell as
steak so what they do is they glue them
all together with fibrin from Pig blood
into this really large sausage then
freeze the sausage cut it in little
slices and sell those as steak again and
um this also actually happens with tuna
and scallops
so with the steak you might drink a beer

Cloudy elements in the beer so to get

uh so this is actually a healthier

the collagen is as

so the most beautiful thing I found at
least what I think is the most beautiful
in the book is uh this heart valve it's
actually a very lowtech and very
high-tech product at the same time the
lowtech bit is that it's literally a
pig's heart valve mounted in the

implanted into a human heart without
open heart surgery and once it's in the
right spot they remove the outer shell
and the Heart f
well it it gets this shape and at that
moment it starts beating instantly it's

is actually a Dutch company so um I
called them up and I asked can I borrow

enthusiastic so they were like okay
we'll put it in a jar for you with
formalin or you can borrow it and great
and then I didn't hear for them from for

asked what's what's going on with the
hard Val and then they said well the
director of the company decided not you
not to borrow you this hard valve
because he doesn't want his product to
be associated with
pigs well the last product from the book
that I'm showing you is renewable energy
actually to show that my first question
if if pigs are still used up until the
last bit was still true well it is
because everything that can't be used
for anything else is made into a fuel
that can be used as a renewable energy
source in total I found 185 products and
um well what this showed me is that well
firstly it's at least to say all that we
don't treat these pigs as absolute kings
and queens and um the second is that we
actually don't have a clue of what all
these products that surround us are made
of and um you might think I'm very fond
of pigs but actually well I am a little
bit but I'm more fond of of raw
materials in general and I think that um
in order to take take better care of
what's behind our products so um the
livestock the crops the plants um the
non-renewable materials but also the

first step would actually be to know
that they're there thank you very much
